comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Ha! I have been waiting for this photo to turn up.  Which part of "Kent Street, The Rocks" was ever bent?.
(Reminds me of an unrepeatable old limerick).

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Right you are - it never did! Thanks to the other photo we've been working on - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2362655413/ - the "Oak" fragment is clearly identifiable as the Royal Oak on Miller's Road, Millers Point. Serendipity!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
35179849@N08
comment._content: Hmm    Hickson road is too straight   and  Kent street is too bent

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Thanks, I hoped you might know about this. It is not easy to identify no-longer-existing streets from 120 year-old photos and maps. Serendipity indeed. Local map (1880) showing Miller's Road - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-rm3424-sd&rgn=0... Resumption Plan F (1900) - gallery.records.nsw.gov.au/wp-content/gallery/darling-har...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Another relevant map from the series: Resumption Plan Y (1901) - gallery.records.nsw.gov.au/wp-content/gallery/darling-har... By looking at those maps it is clear that the photo is taken from the top of Clyde Street. You can see the same ricketty old fence at the top of the hill in this photo - 349. Clyde-street, from No. 18, looking north [SLNSW: a147349]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Terrific id and info.

There is a similar view to this from the corner behind (Bart Street and Millers Road) dated 17/9/1901 on the front dust jacket of Ron Rathbone's "A Very Present Help - Caring for Australians Since 1813 - History of the Benevolent Society of NSW" (State Library of NSW Press 1994).  They credit the photo "from 'Sydney Rocks Area' Vol 2.  Mitchell Library",  but I cannot find it on the SLNSW webisite, or in State Records NSW Series 4481 (yet).  The point about this other photo is that it shows another building (warehouse?) behind the horse and cart, where the stone wall is in this photo.   Meaning that this photo is considerably earlier than the 1901 one,  probably c.1890 like the other Kent Street 'oddities'.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet/galleries/72157627467313436/]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I think you may be referring to "85. [Corner of] Hart St. [&] Miller's Rd., 17.9.01" from the Public Works Department albums of ‘Sydney Rocks Area’ and ‘Old Rocks’ (PXE 921 Vols 1 to 3 - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/search/SimpleSearch.aspx?query=PXE+921... ) that Jenny mentioned on the Archives Outside Blog - archivesoutside.records.nsw.gov.au/uncovering-hidden-trea...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Aha! That is undoubtedly the one. Please excuse Bart for Hart - I'm going blind from staring at these photos! 

It is not available online so here is a snapshot of the book cover photo taken on my phone - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia/6099887186/]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Nice one. This is really bringing the Darling Harbour Resumptions maps to life!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Here is where Miller's Road starts at Kent Street. You can see the same narrow house with the turret window, and also the building at the top of Clyde Street -
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/3810093173/]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Another view in Miller's Road, with the Captain Cook Hotel at left - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/6104227989/]Note the courtyard between the Hart Street and Clyde Street buildings at right, which can also be seen on the "Plan Y" map - gallery.records.nsw.gov.au/wp-content/gallery/darling-har...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] I would say that photo is another in the "Kent Street Exploding Sewer Mystery Series", also c.1890, from the vignetting.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Wow, now you're making our brains hurt! Great detective work - we'll update the caption to Miller's Road, The Rocks. Just to clarify, what corner do you think this photo was taken from: Clyde or Hart?

AB

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] imho "Millers Road (off Kent Street), Millers Point" would make it more findable in searches.  Does Millers Point count as The Rocks?  From the top of Clyde Street (not Hart).

Date: c.1890 (until the Kent St exploding sewer saga is solved).

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] The book cover photo [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] supplied, taken from a short distance back, is the one at the corner of Hart.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia]  Strictly speaking, Millers Point is not part of The Rocks, but adjacent to it. However, much of Millers Point and Dawes Point are commonly included as part of The Rocks in popular usage. So, no and yes :)
